channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: France Denounces Revelations of Spying by N.S.A.
item.description: The government reacted with anger after WikiLeaks released reports of extensive eavesdropping by the United States of senior French leaders, including three presidents.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: WikiLeaks revelations suggest that the United States has been eavesdropping on senior French leaders, including President François Hollande, front.

item.title: Shabab Claim Responsibility for Deadly Car Bomb in Mogadishu
item.description: At least two people were killed in the Somali capital when militants detonated a vehicle loaded with explosives and engaged in a firefight, witnesses and officials said.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Debt Talks May Be Defining Moment for Greece, and for Angela Merkel
item.description: Beyond economics, the outcome of the negotiations will have lasting ramifications for European unity and security, raising questions about the German leader’s legacy.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany finds herself at the pivot of at least three crises in Europe: a potential exit from the currency or bloc by Greece, the danger that Britain might leave the European Union as well, and a newly assertive Russia.

item.title: Israel Cancels Some Gazans’ Access to Al Aqsa Mosque During Ramadan
item.description: The move is the latest effort by Tel Aviv this week to rescind gestures that were intended to ease movement into Israeli-controlled territory for the Muslim holy month.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Palestinians passed through a checkpoint into Jerusalem from the West Bank on Friday to pray at the Al Aqsa Mosque.

item.title: Death Toll From Karachi, Pakistan, Heat Wave Rises to 770
item.description: Continued power cuts and high temperatures contributed to a sense of crisis in Karachi, where thousands have been treated for dehydration and heatstroke.
item.dc:creator: SABA IMTIAZ
item.media:description: Pakistanis took shelter in the shade outside a hospital in Karachi, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Documents on 2012 Drone Strike Detail How Terrorists Are Targeted
item.description: British files provided by Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor, include information on how terrorism suspects are targeted and how drone strikes can go awry.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:credit: Lt. Col. Leslie Pratt/U.S. Air Force, via Reuters
item.media:description: A United States Air Force drone. Strikes by the unmanned aircraft have come under fresh scrutiny after President Obama disclosed in April that an attack had killed two Western aid workers held hostage by Al Qaeda in Pakistan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 100,000 Tons of Smuggled Meat, Some From 1970s, Seized Across China
item.description: The chicken wings, beef and pork uncovered in a customs operation in 14 provinces and regions were valued at up to $483 million, and 20 people have been arrested, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The
item.dc:creator: CRYSTAL TSE
item.media:description: A customer considering the offerings at a meat market in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Opens New Land Route to Tibet for Indian Pilgrims
item.description: The crossing on Monday of Nathu La signaled the official opening of a new pilgrimage route for Indians to the holy sites of Mount Kailash and Lake Manasarovar.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Two 8-year-old American girls on the Kailash pilgrimage trail with Indian tourists in orange jackets.

item.title: Deadly Clash Between Police and Ethnic Uighurs Reported in Xinjiang Region of China
item.description: More than a dozen people were killed in the violence Monday, according to a Radio Free Asia report that was largely corroborated by local residents.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Colombia Military Accused of Deception on Civilian Deaths
item.description: Human Rights Watch says Colombian prosecutors face numerous obstacles in trying to hold high-level officials in the armed forces accountable for killings, in which civilians are presented as armed insurgents.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Sister Nirmala Joshi, Successor to Mother Teresa, Dies at 81
item.description: Sister Nirmala Joshi, former leader of the Roman Catholic order Missionaries of Charity, died Tuesday in Kolkata, India, where the organization is based.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Sister Nirmala Joshi was selected to lead the Roman Catholic order Missionaries of Charity six months before the death of Mother Teresa, right.

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: 17 Are Indicted in U.S. on Cocaine Trafficking Charges
item.description: Members and associates of one of Colombia’s largest and most influential narcotics cartels, including its founder and current leader, have been indicted on drug trafficking charges.
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: British Teenagers Are Charged With Stealing From Auschwitz Site
item.description: The unidentified Britons were accused of stealing artifacts, including a razor, buttons and pieces of glass and cutlery, which once belonged to prisoners at the camps.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: A Timeline of Jews in Egypt
item.description: The number of Egyptian Jews has dwindled to only a few dozen today, from as many as 85,000 in the middle of the last century.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Deadly Fire Hits Nursing Home
item.description: A fire Tuesday killed 16 residents of a nursing home on the outskirts of Mexicali, the capital of Baja California, officials said.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: NATO Refocuses on the Kremlin, Its Original Foe
item.description: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lithuanian and American soldiers at the start of the exercise, intended to show resolve on the new front between NATO and Russia.

item.title: WikiLeaks Files Said to Show N.S.A. Spied on French Leaders
item.description: The documents, which have not been confirmed as authentic, say the agency eavesdropped on the last three French presidents.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: President François Hollande in Brussels on Monday after talks on Greece's debt crisis. WikiLeaks published documents that says the N.S.A. eavesdropped on three French presidents.

item.title: Quebec Leader Defends Limits on Freedom of Expression
item.description: Premier Philippe Couillard said he supported legislation that would restrict Islamic face-coverings for women and hateful speech deemed to foment violence.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader, Khamenei, Seems to Pull Back on Nuclear Talks
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei ruled out a freeze on Iran’s sensitive nuclear work for long periods and insisted that all sanctions must be lifted immediately.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, shown in March, appeared to undercut several agreements his negotiators have reached with the West.

item.title: U.S. Scolds China for Online Attacks
item.description: Top officials meeting with Chinese aides in Washington complained about online attacks on business but kept quiet about the hacking of federal employees’ data.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES
